en.title: Super Gnomatic Strata Analyzer
en.restartDesc: Press CONFIRM to restart at the beginning of the level.
en.introDialog1: This is the Super Gnomatic Strata Analyzer.  A bouncy contraption capable of transmogrifying information from rock layers found in the deep underbelly of Earth.
en.introDialog2: But before we have a crack at it, let's first review the study of rock layers.
en.introStratigraphyDetail1: A study in geology that deals with the order and position of rock layers (strata).
en.introStratigraphyDetail2: Each layer of strata can give us information about the earth's past.  These are categorized in geological time scale.
en.introLawStratigraphySuperpositionDesc: Younger layers of rock sit atop older rocks.
en.introLawStratigraphyOriginalHorizontalit: Sedimentary rocks were originally deposited horizontally by weathering and erosions.  Layers that are tilted have since been altered by external force.
en.introLawStratigraphyCrossCuttingDesc: A layer of rock that cuts across other layers is considered to be younger.
en.introLawStratigraphyLateralContinuityDes: Layers of rock are continuous until they are blocked or broken up by external force.
en.introDialog3: Now that you have learned the basis of stratigraphy, it's time to take the Gnomatic Strata Analyzer for a spin!
en.rock_igneous_gabbro_desc: Gabbro is an intrusive igneous rock. Its color is usually black or dark green. Gabbro is commonly found in the deep oceanic crust.
en.rock_metamorphic_gneiss_desc: Gneiss is a foliated metamorphic rock. Its foliations are characterized by alternating dark and light bands. Gneiss is typically formed from shale that undergoes high pressure and heat.
en.rock_ingeous_granite_desc: Granite is a light-colored igneous rock with large visible grains. It's mostly composed of quartz and feldspar.
en.rock_metamorphic_quartzite_desc: Quartzite is a non-foliated metamorphic rock. It's mostly composed of quartz from sandstone after it undergoes high pressure and heat.
en.result_1_question: Which layer of rock is the youngest:
en.result_1_end: By observing the layers, and where the magma is located; we can determine which one is the intrusive layer. By following the Cross-cutting Relationships in Laws of Stratigraphy, the intrusive layer is the youngest of the layer.
en.result_2_question: Which one of these is an Index Fossil?
en.result_2_end:
Index Fossils are fossils that have only lived a tiny lifespan over a huge area.

These are the criteria:
- The fossil must be easily recognizable and distinct.
- It must be found over a large area.
- It must have lived for a short time, such that it's only found in one stratum.
